text: When you start a new project, you mentally map out how each piece connects to the final outcome before diving into tasks.
In the last month, you caught yourself thinking about what your team or organization will need six months from now, even when nobody asked you to.
When a process has worked fine for a year, you still find yourself questioning whether there is a fundamentally better way to do it.
You usually deal with problems one at a time as they come up, rather than looking at how they might be related.
When you have limited resources, you instinctively know which two or three things to focus on that will create the biggest ripple effect.
When you hear about a change in your industry, your mind immediately runs through three or four downstream consequences.
You spend so much time planning for future scenarios that you sometimes miss deadlines on current work.
When your first approach to a problem fails, you tend to look for a completely different angle rather than just tweaking the original plan.
When you look at your team's current priorities, you can clearly explain how each one connects to where you need to be in a year.
In the last month, you made a decision primarily based on what would pay off in six-plus months, even though it created short-term friction.
You rarely question the assumptions behind a plan that is already working.
When you see a risk that others have not noticed, you bring it up even if it makes the conversation uncomfortable.
You tend to focus on what is right in front of you and let the long-term sort itself out.
In the last month, you borrowed an idea from a completely different field and applied it to your own work.
When you spot a shortcut that would save time now but create problems later, you flag it and push for the longer path.
You find it hard to explain to others why something that seems unimportant now will matter later.
When you come up with a new approach, you test it on a small scale before proposing a full rollout.
When someone asks you why you made a specific decision, you can trace it back to a larger goal without hesitating.
You often get so deep into analyzing possibilities that you delay making a decision until the window has nearly closed.
When you see how different people's work fits together toward a bigger outcome, you make sure they see it too.
When your team hits a wall, you tend to keep trying harder with the current approach rather than rethinking the problem entirely.
In the last month, you identified a trend early enough that your team had time to prepare before it hit.
When an assumption you have relied on turns out to be wrong, you find it energizing rather than unsettling to rebuild your mental model.
You prefer to take things as they come rather than work from a plan you mapped out in advance.
I can always predict market changes before they happen.

Your company has budget to invest in one area this quarter. Sales wants more headcount, engineering wants to rebuild a core system, and marketing wants to launch in a new channel. Each team has strong data supporting their case. You have to recommend one.

options.text: Map out how each investment would compound over 18 months and pick the one with the highest long-term leverage, even if it is not the most urgent.
Talk to each team lead one-on-one to understand what they are really worried about, then find a solution that addresses the deepest concern.
Go with whichever investment closes the most obvious gap right now so the company does not lose ground this quarter.
Split the budget across all three at reduced levels so no team feels left out and everyone makes some progress.

text: A regulation change is being discussed that could affect your industry in 12 to 18 months. Nothing is finalized yet. Your peers are ignoring it because it may not pass.

options.text: Build two contingency plans now, one for if it passes and one for if it does not, so you can move fast either way.
Wait until the regulation is finalized, then mobilize quickly. No point planning for something that might not happen.
Bring it up at the next leadership meeting so the team is at least aware, even if you do not act yet.
Quietly start adjusting your own work to be ready, but do not raise it publicly until there is more certainty.

text: Your team's main product has been successful for three years, but growth is slowing. A junior team member suggests a radical redesign. The rest of the team thinks it is too risky.

options.text: Give the junior member a small team and two weeks to build a prototype. If it shows promise, expand the experiment.
Acknowledge the idea publicly, but focus the team on optimizing what is already working. Do not fix what is not broken.
Run a structured analysis of the redesign idea alongside two other alternatives, then let data decide.
Use the idea as a springboard for a broader team brainstorm about what the product should look like in two years.

text: You are halfway through a six-month project when new information suggests the original goal may no longer be the right target. Your team has already invested significant effort.

options.text: Pause the project for a week to reassess the goal against the new information, even though it will slow delivery.
Push through to the original deadline. Pivoting now would waste the work already done and demoralize the team.
Adjust the scope to incorporate the new information without abandoning the original direction entirely.
Present both paths to the team and let them weigh in before deciding. They are closest to the work.

text: A key supplier raises their prices 20%. Your competitors are scrambling to find alternatives. You have enough margin to absorb the increase for now.

options.text: Use this as a trigger to diversify your supply chain now, treating it as the early warning sign it probably is.
Absorb the cost for this quarter and revisit later. Do not overreact to a single price change.
Negotiate hard with the supplier. Loyalty should count for something, and you have been a reliable customer.
Pass the cost to customers immediately. Transparency about pricing protects the business long-term.

text: You notice that two departments are solving similar problems with completely different tools and processes. Neither knows what the other is doing.

options.text: Set up a meeting between both teams to share approaches. One might learn from the other, or they might combine into something better.
Study both approaches to figure out which one is more scalable, then recommend the company standardize on that one.
Flag it to leadership as a coordination gap and let them decide how to handle it.
Leave it alone. Different teams have different needs, and forcing alignment could slow both of them down.

text: Your team hits their quarterly targets, but you notice the wins came from a few lucky breaks rather than a repeatable system. Everyone else is celebrating.

options.text: Celebrate with the team, then privately begin building systems so the next quarter does not depend on luck.
Raise the concern openly. The team needs to know that these results are not sustainable.
Let it ride. Morale matters, and the team earned the celebration. Address systems next quarter.
Set higher targets for next quarter. If they hit those too, the system is working fine.

text: A new technology is getting a lot of buzz in your industry. Some companies are investing heavily. Others are calling it overhyped. You need to advise your leadership team.

options.text: Research how this technology could specifically change your value chain, then recommend targeted experiments in the areas with highest impact.
Wait for early adopters to succeed or fail. Learning from their mistakes is cheaper than being the guinea pig.
Hire an outside expert to give an objective assessment. You should not bet the company on your own judgment alone.
Ask your frontline teams what problems they have that this technology might solve. Start from their pain, not the hype.

text: Your biggest client wants a custom feature that would take your product in a direction you had not planned. The revenue is significant, but it would pull engineering off the roadmap for two months.

options.text: Evaluate whether this request reveals a market need you missed. If it does, incorporate it into the roadmap as a strategic feature, not a one-off.
Build it. Keeping your biggest client happy is the priority, and you can return to the roadmap after.
Offer a workaround that partially solves their need without derailing the roadmap.
Be transparent that it does not align with your direction. If the client leaves, that tells you something important about product-market fit.

text: You are asked to present your three-year vision to the board. Your honest assessment is that the market is too volatile to predict beyond 12 months with any confidence.

options.text: Present a 12-month plan with clear milestones, plus three plausible scenarios for years two and three with decision triggers for each.
Build the best three-year plan you can. Boards need confidence, and you can adjust as you go.
Tell the board honestly that three-year planning is unreliable right now and propose a rolling 12-month approach instead.
Ask other leaders on your team to contribute their three-year outlook for their areas, then weave it into a combined view.

text: Your team's workload has been manageable, but you see three separate projects converging in the same month six weeks from now. Nobody else has flagged it yet.

options.text: Start redistributing workloads now so the team has breathing room when the convergence hits.
Bring it to the team's attention and let them decide how to prepare. They know their capacity best.
Wait a couple of weeks to see if timelines shift. Things often resolve themselves.
Flag it to your manager and recommend that one of the three projects be moved. Better to disappoint one stakeholder than burn out the whole team.

text: A competitor launches a product that copies your core feature but offers it for free. Your sales team is panicking.

options.text: Use this as the push to differentiate. If they can copy your current feature, you need to be building the next one already.
Cut your price to match. Losing market share now will be harder to recover from than a temporary margin hit.
Double down on customer relationships and service quality. Features can be copied, but trust cannot.
Analyze exactly what they copied and what they missed. The gaps tell you what they do not understand about your customers.

text: You have been promoted and now oversee three teams that historically have not collaborated well. Each has its own goals and metrics that sometimes conflict.

options.text: Redesign the metrics so all three teams share at least one common outcome they can only achieve together.
Spend your first month listening to each team's frustrations with the others before changing anything.
Set up a weekly cross-team standup so they at least know what each other is working on.
Let each team keep running independently. They have been successful in their own right, and forced collaboration often backfires.

text: Your company is growing fast. You can see that the processes that work at your current size will break at double the headcount, but everyone is focused on hiring.

options.text: Start investing in scalable systems now, before the cracks show. It is easier to build infrastructure during calm than during a crisis.
Focus on hiring the right people. Good people will figure out the process problems when they arise.
Document the concerns and share them with leadership so the risk is on record, even if they choose not to act now.
Fix processes only as they break. Premature optimization wastes resources on problems that may never materialize.

text: During a routine review, you realize your team has been solving the wrong problem for two weeks. The work is high quality, but pointed in the wrong direction.

options.text: Stop the work, redefine the problem clearly, and redirect. Two weeks of sunk cost is better than two months.
See if the work can be repurposed toward the actual problem. There may be salvageable pieces.
Let the team finish the current sprint, then redirect. Stopping mid-stream is demoralizing.
Dig into how the misalignment happened so you can prevent it next time, then redirect.

text: You have a strategic idea that you believe in strongly, but your data is incomplete and your team is skeptical. You need their buy-in to move forward.

options.text: Propose a small, low-risk test that would generate the missing data. Let the results do the persuading.
Make the case with the data you have, be transparent about what is missing, and ask for a conditional go-ahead.
Shelve it. If you cannot convince your own team, maybe the idea is not as strong as you think.
Find one ally on the team who sees the potential and build momentum from there.

text: Your industry is stable now, but you read an analysis suggesting a major disruption could happen within five years. The analysis is from a credible source, but the timing is uncertain.

options.text: Begin building capabilities now that would be valuable whether or not the disruption happens. Hedge your bet.
Set up a quarterly review to track leading indicators of the disruption so you are not caught off guard.
Share the analysis widely so the organization is aware, but do not change strategy based on a five-year prediction.
Focus on strengthening current customer relationships. A loyal customer base is your best defense against any disruption.

text: Your business is profitable but plateauing. Your gut says:

options.text: Something fundamental about our model needs to change before the plateau becomes a decline.
We need to execute harder on what is already working. Discipline beats reinvention.

text: A competitor makes a surprising move. Your first thought is:

options.text: What do they see coming that we do not?
How do we respond to protect our position right now?

text: When someone brings you a problem, you tend to:

options.text: Ask what caused the problem in the first place, because the real fix is usually upstream.
Focus on solving it quickly so the person can get back to work.

text: You are building next year's plan. You open with:

options.text: Where do we need to be in three years, and what do we need to start now to get there?
What did we learn this year, and how do we do more of what worked?

text: A decision needs to be made by Friday. You have 70% of the information you want. You:

options.text: Decide now. Waiting for perfect information usually means missing the window.
Spend until Thursday gathering the remaining data. The quality of this decision matters more than the speed.

text: You read something fascinating from a completely unrelated industry. Your instinct is:

options.text: Interesting, but not relevant to my work. I should stay focused on my own domain.
There might be a principle here I can borrow. Let me think about how it maps to what I am doing.

text: Two people on your team disagree about priorities. You step in and:

options.text: Ask both of them which priority connects more directly to the outcome that matters most this quarter.
Hear both sides out, then help them find a compromise they can both live with.

text: You notice a small inefficiency that costs the company $500 a month. Everyone else ignores it. You:

options.text: Fix it. Small leaks sink big ships, and this pattern probably shows up in other places too.
Let it go. There are bigger problems to solve, and spending energy on this is a distraction.

text: You encounter a complex problem. You naturally start by:

options.text: Zooming out to see the full picture and how the pieces relate before touching any of them.
Picking the most concrete piece and solving it first to build momentum.

text: Your team just finished a project. Before starting the next one, you want to:

options.text: Run a quick retrospective on what worked and what did not, so the next project starts smarter.
Jump into the next project while energy is high. Momentum matters more than reflection right now.
